column1: Periodontitis is inflammation and infection of the ligaments and bones that support the teeth.
Periodontitis occurs when inflammation or infection of the gums (gingivitis) is allowed to progress without treatment.
Infection and inflammation spreads from the gums (gingiva) to the ligaments and bone that support the teeth.
Periodontitis is the primary cause of tooth loss in adults.
This disorder is uncommon in young children, but increases during the teen years.
Deposits of plaque and tartar may be seen at the base of the teeth and the pockets in the gums may be enlarged.
The goal of treatment is to reduce inflammation, remove "pockets" in the gums, and treat any underlying causes of gum disease.
This may involve use of various tools to loosen and remove plaque and tartar from the teeth.
Proper flossing and brushing is always needed, even after professional tooth cleaning, to reduce your risk of gum disease.
Some people find the removal of dental plaque from inflamed gums to be uncomfortable.
Bleeding and tenderness of the gums should go away within 1 or 2 weeks of treatment.
